ï»¿ 67481 Bub ley INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT
TWO HUNDRED NINETY-SECOND REGULAR MEETING of EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS
Board Room International Bank Building Washington, D. C. Thur~day, October 17, 1957
The meeting was convened at 10:05 a.m., Mr. Eugene R. Black, PreSident, presiding.  2
Agenda Item
Operational Report to the Executive Directors â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢ 25
Mr. Cargill Supplemental Report â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢ 25
** ** **  25
i i
I MR. BLACK:
The next item on the agenda is the Operational Report
covering the period from september 10 to October 7. Are
J there any questions on this report? If there are no questions, I would like to calIon Mr. Cargill to supplement the report. MR. CARGILL: l\lr. Chairman, during the Annual Meeting the Japanese Minister of Finance informed the Bank regarding Japan's program for external borrowing during the next three or four years and suggested projects for Barn, consideration in the fields of pOl.'1er, transportation" and private industry which might involve loans of something like $300 million.  26
He explained that it would not be feasible to find projects involving sufficient foreign exchange expenditures to make upl this amount and asked the Bank to consider extending loans in part for local currency expenditures in order to carry out this program.
The President of the Bank informed the Minister that the total external borrowing program proposed by Japan seemed reasonable within the limits of their repayment capaCity as we now understood the Japanese economic situation, but that he did not wish to enter into any understanding about a definite program of loans which he was prepared to recommend
to the Board.
He added that the Bank would be prepared to review parÂ­ ticular projects which would be submitted for financing to see if they were technically and economically sound, and that in principle the proposal to finance local currency expendiÂ­ tures would be acceptable provided that the Bank's financing was kept within reasonable proportions of the total expendiÂ­ tures involved. The Japanese have now asked the Bank to review 11 proÂ­ jects as the basis for loans under these arrangements. The projects would call for the expansion of four steel plants, for the construction of six hydroelectric projects, and for a toll road to be built between Kobe and Nagoya. With regard to the steel projects, two of the companies  27
have already borro'Vled from the Bank and in the case of one" the Kawasaki Steel Corporation" the Bank's knowledge of the proposed expansion is sufficient for us to enter into negotiations fairly early. The remaining projects will reÂ­ quire further examination, probably in Japan. With regard to the six power projects, it has been arranged that a technical mission should visit Japan in November to commence a study of them. The road project is still in a preliminary stage of investigation. The Government is thinking of financing its construction partly by a loan from the Bank and partly by a bond issue in the New York market" but final decisions on this case can not be taken for some time. MR. BLACK: Any questions? Mr. Larre. MR. LARRE: May I ask whether there is any hint of what is the amount that the Japanese Government is looking to borrow from the Bank in this? I donlt think they are going to borrow $300 million from the Bank alone. Is there any figure which has been put forward? MR. CARGILL: That is the figure. MR. BLACK: That is the figure" $300 million. MR. CARGILL: Over the next three or four years. MR. LARRE : That is from the Bank?
MR. CARGILL: Yes.

doc.repnme: Transcript of two hundred ninety-second regular meeting of the Executive Directors of the IBRD, held on Thursday, October 17, 1957
doc.abstracts: This transcript, from the session of the Executive Directors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development held on Thursday, October 17, 1957, covers only the discussion of two hundred ninety-second regular meeting.
